document_title: High-precision method for cyclic loading of small-animal vertebrae to assess bone quality
summary_full: This paper presents a novel, high-precision method for ex vivo cyclic compressive loading of isolated mouse vertebral bodies, addressing challenges posed by the small size of these bones and machine compliance. The method incorporates 3D-printed jigs for precise machining of vertebral surfaces, pivotable loading platens for uniform contact, and specimen-specific micro-CT-based finite element analysis to determine stiffness and prescribe forces that ensure a consistent strain level across all specimens. When compared to two common literature methods, this new approach significantly reduced scatter in mechanical behavior, particularly in fatigue life measurements, with a standard deviation up to 5-fold lower. The improved precision is expected to enhance statistical power in small-animal studies, aiding in the elucidation of bone quality aspects related to aging, disease, and treatment.
key_findings: Developed a high-precision method for ex vivo cyclic loading of mouse vertebrae using 3D-printed jigs, pivotable platens, and micro-CT-based FEA.
The new method significantly reduced scatter in fatigue life measurements compared to existing literature methods (up to 5-fold lower standard deviation).
Achieved a consistent strain level across specimens by calculating specimen-specific forces based on FEA-derived stiffness.
Demonstrated reduced variation in stiffness and strain-to-failure measurements.
The method showed no correlation between applied force and fatigue life, indicating a constant fatigue life across specimens under controlled strain.
future_research_fields: Investigating the effects of aging, disease, and treatments on bone quality using the improved precision of this method.
Applying the method to other small animal models (e.g., rats, bovine) with potential adjustments for specimen-specific modulus.
Further optimization of specimen preparation and FEA parameters for enhanced accuracy.
Exploring the application of this method to monotonic testing of small-animal vertebrae.

conclusions: The developed high-precision method for cyclic loading of small-animal vertebrae significantly reduces variability in mechanical testing outcomes, particularly fatigue life. By controlling for specimen-specific strain levels through micro-CT-based finite element analysis and employing precise mechanical fixtures, this technique offers improved statistical power for studies investigating bone quality changes due to aging, disease, or therapeutic interventions, especially when limited sample sizes are a constraint.
impact_statement: This study introduces a more precise biomechanical testing method for small-animal vertebrae, crucial for accurately assessing bone quality and improving the detection of subtle changes caused by disease or treatment in preclinical research.
